{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3184078,"name":"Jesus Hernandez Garcia","username":"MammothCape35","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/6de8d8/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-04-09T15:42:24.511Z","cooked":"

Thought I’d ask this here, I wanted to know if I connected two routers to one network switch would devices connected to one of the routers be able to talk to each other. For example I’m connected to Router 1 and J want to print to a printer on Router 2 would that network configuration make that possible?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-04-09T15:42:24.511Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":224,"readers_count":223,"score":54.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":433541,"topic_slug":"not-frc-question-but-rather-a-general-it-network-question","display_username":"Jesus Hernandez Garcia","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57671,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/not-frc-question-but-rather-a-general-it-network-question/433541/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3184082,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-04-09T15:45:15.133Z","cooked":"

It depends on how you configure the routers. That’s the configuration I have at home.

BUT, fair warning: printer networking can be wonky, especially over wifi.

Yeah, what configurations should I use? I currently have a ASUS ROG router and a Netgear NIGHTHAWK

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-04-09T16:23:47.202Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":182,"readers_count":181,"score":41.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":433541,"topic_slug":"not-frc-question-but-rather-a-general-it-network-question","display_username":"Jesus Hernandez Garcia","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":28649,"username":"CEF","name":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57671,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/not-frc-question-but-rather-a-general-it-network-question/433541/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3184140,"name":"Jared Hasen-Klein","username":"jaredhk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jaredhk/{size}/248125_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-09T16:57:02.261Z","cooked":"

This is, essentially, what corporate networks do, even very large ones. If you’re somewhere with a massive network (big office building, college campus, etc.) odds are that you’re connected to the same network regardless of where you are, but you’re connecting via a different access point as you move floor to floor, building to building, etc. In many cases, there are printers (or other devices) on the network.

The larger the network, generally the more complicated the management gets. But conceptually, yes it is certainly possible.

You’ll want to make sure you set up both routers/APs on the same network rather than trying to broadcast two networks that happen to have the same names. Once they’re on the same network, get your printer on the network. Assuming you’re not doing any fancy networking (VLANs, etc.) you should be able to print irrespective of the access point you’re connected to.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-04-09T16:57:02.261Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":143,"readers_count":142,"score":28.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":433541,"topic_slug":"not-frc-question-but-rather-a-general-it-network-question","display_username":"Jared Hasen-Klein","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://homenetworkgeek.com/how-to-setup-two-routers-on-the-same-network/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":24866,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/not-frc-question-but-rather-a-general-it-network-question/433541/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3184148,"name":"Joe Ross","username":"Joe_Ross","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joe_ross/{size}/37_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-09T17:01:56.401Z","cooked":"

The configuration will depend on how you connect them.

If you connect both router’s WAN ports to the switch, then NAT would keep you from communicating and you’d need to disable NAT.
If you connect both router’s LAN ports to the switch, then you’d have two DHCP servers, and you’d need to turn off DHCP on one of them.

As long as one of the routers is a DHCP server and the other router is a access point, then it should work.
